awd_titl_txt: Mean Curvature Flow and Minimal Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
The Principal Investigator will study mean curvature flow, a natural process by which geometric shapes change over time.  In mathematics, mean curvature flow and similar flows have proved to be very important: in particular, the closely related Ricci flow has been very much in the news because of its essential role in the solution of the long-standing Poincare conjecture. Mean curvature flow also arises in the physical world.  For example, grain boundaries in annealing metals move by mean curvature flow. The Principal Investigator will also investigate minimal surfaces.  Minimal surfaces are equilibrium shapes for mean curvature flow, that is, shapes that do not change over time.  In astronomy, minimal surfaces occur as  "apparent horizons" of black holes. Here on earth, soap films provide examples of minimal surfaces.  Minimal surfaces are of great theoretical interest: tools first discovered in the study of minimal surfaces have proved to be valuable in many other areas of mathematics.

The Principal Investigator plans to study properties of mean curvature flow,especially singularity formation and the non-uniqueness known as "fattening".  Specific goals include determining whether generic surfaces give rise to smaller spacetime singular sets than do arbitrary initial surfaces, understanding the causes of fattening, and discovering natural conditions that prevent fattening.  He also plans to investigate minimal varieties, including topics such as the behavior of the recently-discovered genus-g helicoids as the genus tends to infinity, the relationship between properties of a minimal surface and the total curvature of its boundary, the fine structure of branch points of minimal surfaces (and, in particular, whether the Micallef-White necessary conditions for a minimal surface to be area-minimizing near a branch point are also sufficient), and the relationship between topology and density at singularities of minimal varieties.

por.por_cntn:
Mean curvature flow is a process under which geometric shapes evolve in time.  It was originally introduced to model grain boundaries in annealing metals.  It can also be used to model the way that a soap film comes to equilibrium.  Together with collaborators David Hoffman and Francisco Martin, I was able to discover and classify some important new kinds of surfaces that arise in mean curvature flow: Scherk translators, helicoid-like translators, Scherkenoids, and pitchfork translators.  Other important translating surfaces called tridents were discovered by Nguyen. We found that there are many more tridents in addition to the ones that Nguyen discovered.  Indeed, we succeeded in classifying all tridents.


Another interesting class of surface that arise in mean curvature flow are the ``shrinkers": the surfaces that evolve under mean curvature by shrinking but without otherwise changing shape.  Understanding the shrinkers is important because any time a singularity develops in mean curvature flow, then, if one looks at the surface under a microscope just before the singularity, one sees a surface that is very close to a shrinker.  One of the most important measures of a shrinker is its entropy.   Or Hershkovits and I were able to provea precise relationship between the entropy of a shrinker and its topology.


Most research on mean curvature flow has focused on surfaces without boundary.  However, it is also very natural to consider mean curvature flow for surfaces with boundary.   For example, this is the correct framework for modeling non-equilibrium soap films. In a paper that has appeared in the journal Ars Inveniendi Analytica, I develop the theory of mean curvature flow for surfaces with boundary.  In another preprint, I develop the theory further, showing that interesting boundary singularities can occur, and applying the theory to answer some old questions in minimal surface theory.
